IT could have been salvaged at the end by having the soldier be one of the wounded from the sons unit, but didn't happen so ruined it for me. I know this is out of step with most reviews, but we all have different likes &  dislikes.
summary: Not "The Christmas Card" by a long shot.

reviewText: This is my favorite as the actors are all excellent and the subject deals with the son killed in Afghanistan during Christmas time.  The family gives up Christmas as a result until a soldier from the same unit comes to visit the family by chance.  I loved the way the town represents the Christmas season and reminds me of the era of Desert storm when we first went into the mideast conflict.  William Devane is exceptional as well as all the characters.  It  honors all those who served and gave their lives for us.

reviewText: One of my favorite parts of the Christmas season are the television movies.  They are sometimes sentimental and sappy.  Those are my favorites.  A Christmas Visitor is one of my recent favorites.  The story of a family who has lost a son in the first Persian Gulf war is as relevant today as it would have been 20 years ago.  This story is about healing and letting go.  It is about family, hope and love.  It is a beautifully-acted film with realistic characters and it is one that I look forward to seeing each Christmas season.

reviewText: Wonderful film.  This family's struggle in the aftermath of the death of one of the children in wartime at the expense of Christmas and the ceasing to celebrate the reason for the season caused me to think of our many serving now in the conflicts around the world.  The tragedy for the young daughter, the senseless cessation of 'living' for her young life at the time of the death of her brother brought tears to my eyes.  The conflict, the inner battles of the parents to adjust to the loss, magnified by the fact that 'memorializing' and remembering the fallen year after year, made me think of what I would do under the same circumstances.  Grieving the loss of a child, not what we are supposed to have to do, and the effect it had on the surviving daughter and her young life gave me reason to think.  God's provision of a 'visitor' who brought Christmas back to them in all ways touched my heart.  This film is well worth the price.  To see and feel the emotion of this family, and to know that 'comfort and joy' are out there was amazing.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love this movie. I watch it every year. The quality of the blu-ray is excellent. It's widescreen, which I wasn't expecting, but I didn't notice any cropping from the 4:3 aspect of when the movie airs on tv. It's a great Christmas classic that everyone in the family can watch. Sure, the film can seem flat at times, but you don't really notice that all that much. The last half of the movie is the best part of it, when the family gets Christmas back in their lives after 12 years. I would definately recommend picking this up if you've seen it and love it as much as I do.

reviewText: The title/tag line of my review really says it: I like this story just fine, but, for my 90-something mom, it's a real classic, to enjoy again and again and, not solely at Christmas time!The crux of the story is not a *great mystery* -- it's readily suspected, early-on, so I'll not spoil anything for anyone by this review, I'm quite sure. The Christmas Visitor is predictable, but good. I believe you can safely read to the end of my thoughts here.My mom admires the acting, thoroughly enjoys the characters, the love, loss, challenge, joy, possibility; the undying love that bridges all separation and the quiet gratitude that the story portrays. The acting is quite good: we both would agree that the mom's anger and pain is well-depicted by Meridith Baxter; the sister's sense of deep loss well done and, William Devane brings his quiet, steady warmth and likeability to the character of the father.It's all a better *package*/storyline than most Hallmark offerings, I would agree -- if one believes/has hopes for or faith in life-after-death, or is intrigued by some sort of afterlife/continuum. I can imagine this story being a prompt for family/friend discussions of this oft-speculated upon subject.
summary: It's fine for me -- BUT, my mom really LOVES this movie!
